snippet.textDisplay: If these companies were smart they would offer a service agreement for all their products, new or used,  that includes online diagnostics and parts support.  The only thing you wont get is a warranty unless the work is completed by a certified technician.  Win Win. Most everything now has WiFi / Bluetooth.  If not then create a Wi-Fi adapter that can be plugged into a data port and offer it as an addition to the service package. All someone will need is a smart phone or WiFi connection in their barn.  Make the service package extremely affordable and offer discounts on parts and services for those that use their app to order parts and track their services.  There is a way to do this.

snippet.textDisplay: So a lot of you think it’s complete bs that y’all can’t work on this equipment yourself and I agree but I’m going to try to give you a new perspective so I work in a different industry but we provide heavy equipment and I’m a field service technician so I can relate to John Deere I’ve seen multiple customers cost them selves way more money because a third party company or repairman aka tech tried to repair there equipment they have no clue on how the equipment function causing way more damage I’ve worked on other manufacturers equipment and thank god I knew someone that company if not I would’ve caused lots of damage to that piece of equipment and I’m pretty familiar with this equipment also it’s a huge warranty factor you have some third party person working on this equipment and they mess up even with all the computers you can’t always prove that it isn’t a warranty repair so your company if fronting the bill for a repair that wasn’t y’all fault
snippet.textOriginal: So a lot of you think it’s complete bs that y’all can’t work on this equipment yourself and I agree but I’m going to try to give you a new perspective so I work in a different industry but we provide heavy equipment and I’m a field service technician so I can relate to John Deere I’ve seen multiple customers cost them selves way more money because a third party company or repairman aka tech tried to repair there equipment they have no clue on how the equipment function causing way more damage I’ve worked on other manufacturers equipment and thank god I knew someone that company if not I would’ve caused lots of damage to that piece of equipment and I’m pretty familiar with this equipment also it’s a huge warranty factor you have some third party person working on this equipment and they mess up even with all the computers you can’t always prove that it isn’t a warranty repair so your company if fronting the bill for a repair that wasn’t y’all fault

snippet.textDisplay:
Its not just tractors, its washing machines, cookers, fridges, leaf blowers, tv's, mobile phones and computer equipment. All the manufacturers want to produce goods which now wear out and stop repair shops and self repair from fixing anything, so you have no option but to go out and buy new items. The big companies argue that farmers are increasing the power of their tractors and other lies just to put a stop to the right to repair bill, they pay people to go to legislature meetings and lie to put the brakes on this bill. The companies know it will cost them more to produce long lasting products with good quality components, its cheaper to throw in poor quality tech and block the ability of consumers to fix it.



That's why nothing lasts anymore.

snippet.textDisplay: So everyone that is complaining about not letting people use there software. You can buy non dealer levels of the software.  Also dam near every component on the machine uses an ecm or node to control it. Lights, A/C, load meters, moisture senors, injectors, transmissions. Each one of these ecm’s cost thousands of dollars.  So you joe blow farmer has the “right” to own the software to reprogram an ecm.  Well during the flash your computer goes to sleep and now you fried that ecm. Now your out x amount of dollars.  So you joe blow farmer now want the dealer ship to warranty out the ecm that you fried with the knowledge that you don’t have to work on your piece of equipment. As a field tech that has worked in the ag field, heavy field, and truck field the amount of training I’ve had to go to work on equipment to gain the knowledge of working on equipment is insane. And amount of money the dealer have to spend on each tech to train them is silly stupid.  Average cost to send a tech to training for 5 day is around $50k. So to cover the cost of a field tech to go to a machine the dealer has to charge a amount to pay for the yearly cost of software programs, cost of running the field tech, his training cost, and all other expenses. But when of have a dealer tech work on your equipment you hav a warranty.  When you have a shade tree mechanic, with a nice tree with outlets work on the equipment what warranty do you have.  I do agree that it’s stupid that people are not able to work on certain parts of the equipment and vehicles. But if you’re not mechanically inclined to work on a vehicle or a piece of equipment you shouldn’t. Why would I want somebody to work on their own stuff then they mess it up, then I have to go out and fix their mess up which takes longer when they could have just called the dealer and had a mechanic come out right away. And dealers work with customers all the time on bills for labor transport parts. Also diesel around the world just to let you guys know.

Each one of these ecm’s cost thousands of dollars.  So you joe blow farmer has the “right” to own the software to reprogram an ecm.  Well during the flash your computer goes to sleep and now you fried that ecm. Now your out x amount of dollars.  So you joe blow farmer now want the dealer ship to warranty out the ecm that you fried with the knowledge that you don’t have to work on your piece of equipment. As a field tech that has worked in the ag field, heavy field, and truck field the amount of training I’ve had to go to work on equipment to gain the knowledge of working on equipment is insane. I do agree that it’s stupid that people are not able to work on certain parts of the equipment and vehicles. But if you’re not mechanically inclined to work on a vehicle or a piece of equipment you shouldn’t. Why would I want somebody to work on their own stuff then they mess it up, then I have to go out and fix their mess up which takes longer when they could have just called the dealer and had a mechanic come out right away. And dealers work with customers all the time on bills for labor transport parts. Also diesel around the world just to let you guys know.

snippet.textDisplay:
In the end this all comes down to money. The big companies don't want this right to repair act to come to fruition because it lowers their bottom dollar. But they don't see in the long run this could come back to harm that bottom dollar anyways. The At&t spokeswoman brought up something interesting to me: she said if the act passed in the state then most likely the bigger corporations would just decide not to sell there, basically outlawing the state from their market. These bigger companies wouldn't see that it could actually would be a double edged sword for both the companies and the state.

If they stopped selling to say Nebraska in this case then not only would they ruin their market in that state, which in turn cause other big companies such as Verizon or Case International to grow in that market, it would also cause a shift in that states economy. Nebraska to my knowledge does have a thriving agricultural economy and if say John Deere in this case does refuse to sell in Nebraska their softwares to fix these newer tractors then people would just switch over to different manufacturers or use older models which in turn can hurt John Deere's profit margins. Plus it would harm the agricultural industry when say a local farmer can't afford to fix his equipment and have to sell majority of if not all his property to get his equipment working.

In the end it's probably just easier to accept the act and just deal with the consequences of doing so instead of refusing to sell and hurt your business later in life. If the companies like Apple, AT&T, and John Deere don't adapt and accept changes it could hurt them in the foreseeable future, maybe not a lot but it would cause attention.
snippet.textOriginal:
In the end this all comes down to money. The big companies don't want this right to repair act to come to fruition because it lowers their bottom dollar. But they don't see in the long run this could come back to harm that bottom dollar anyways. The At&t spokeswoman brought up something interesting to me: she said if the act passed in the state then most likely the bigger corporations would just decide not to sell there, basically outlawing the state from their market. These bigger companies wouldn't see that it could actually would be a double edged sword for both the companies and the state.

If they stopped selling to say Nebraska in this case then not only would they ruin their market in that state, which in turn cause other big companies such as Verizon or Case International to grow in that market, it would also cause a shift in that states economy. Nebraska to my knowledge does have a thriving agricultural economy and if say John Deere in this case does refuse to sell in Nebraska their softwares to fix these newer tractors then people would just switch over to different manufacturers or use older models which in turn can hurt John Deere's profit margins. Plus it would harm the agricultural industry when say a local farmer can't afford to fix his equipment and have to sell majority of if not all his property to get his equipment working.

In the end it's probably just easier to accept the act and just deal with the consequences of doing so instead of refusing to sell and hurt your business later in life. If the companies like Apple, AT&T, and John Deere don't adapt and accept changes it could hurt them in the foreseeable future, maybe not a lot but it would cause attention.

snippet.textDisplay:
"Customers, dealers, and manufacturers should work together on the issue rather than invite government regulation that could add costs with no associated value." - John Deere
The problem is that you haven't been open to working with your customers. And what added costs? You're forcing people to haul farm equipment at great personal cost to have repairs they could do at home be done by you, just to squeeze them for every last penny. Costs would only go down! To use people's fear of government overreach as a defense for your predatory business practices is despicable. I hope the hard-working men and women who use John Deere products can find suitable alternatives. It deserves to go out of business for this.

snippet.textDisplay:
The bigger picture is that restrictions on repair puts the US food supply at risk for the sake of marginal profits for manufacturers and tech companies. We may have already done that by overloading farm machinery with technology but if the individual farmer cannot self-repair at critical points then food production is potentially compromised.

The solution is to elect more politicians who are not already in the pockets of manufacturers but have the interests of the entire country at heart. The litmus test is not Republican or Democrat but who are you working to serve?

BTW, if I were a Nebraska legislator, I would be offended by the not-so-veiled threats to stop selling in Nebraska if the legislature would dare do anything contradictory to the manufacturer lobby. Get real! If John Deere stopped selling farm equipment in Nebraska, where would they make up the sales? Mars?
snippet.textOriginal:
The bigger picture is that restrictions on repair puts the US food supply at risk for the sake of marginal profits for manufacturers and tech companies.  We may have already done that by overloading farm machinery with technology but if the individual farmer cannot self-repair at critical points then food production is potentially compromised.

The solution is to elect more politicians who are not already in the pockets of manufacturers but have the interests of the entire country at heart.  The litmus test is not Republican or Democrat but who are you working to serve?

BTW, if I were a Nebraska legislator, I would be offended by the not-so-veiled threats to stop selling in Nebraska if the legislature would dare do anything contradictory to the manufacturer lobby.  Get real!  If John Deere stopped selling farm equipment in Nebraska, where would they make up the sales?  Mars?

snippet.textDisplay: I appreciate you uploading this video, but it is the same video that the Motherboard channel uploaded on February 1, 2018.  It would have been nice if it had been updated since then.  For Instance, more states are having hearings on Right to Repair now.  With 6,367 comments in the 5 days since this was uploaded, (the original on Motherboard only has 7,857 comments.  1,319,429 views here on VICE, 3,199,302 on Motherboard).  Also, Louis Rossmann is giving excellent coverage to right to repair on his youtube channel and has practically made himself a one person unpaid lobbyist for the movement.  He could use some help.  Check out his channel and get involved.

snippet.textDisplay:
John Deere's focus is no longer the farm tractor and implement business.  
It is now focused on development of its multinational and self-financing parts and repair controlled leverage scam, something clearly designed to suck all it can out of the pockets of the US farming community, and much in the same way as the banks did in the last century.  
The initial machinery sale is now just the bait in that increasingly evil process.
snippet.textOriginal:
John Deere's focus is no longer the farm tractor and implement business.  
  It is now focused on development of its multinational and self-financing parts and repair controlled leverage scam, something clearly designed to suck all it can out of the pockets of the US farming community, and much in the same way as the banks did in the last century.  
 The initial machinery sale is now just the bait in that increasingly evil process.

snippet.textDisplay: I agree that the diagnostic software should be available for purchase to the public. BUT!!! With that being said, possessing the diagnostic software wont immediately make you a technician capable of diagnosing and properly repairing any issue that pops up on these new machines. Understanding the diag. software and knowing how to properly use it and how to interpret the info it retrieves from the machine is a whole other set of issues.

snippet.textDisplay: If capitalism works then a company will pop up that doesn’t do these things and fill a massive need and make lots of money. Or perhaps there really isn’t a massive need for this and all the companies are doing it because most people actually don’t care if they can fix it themselves, and the benefits of allowing that small percentage to do so is not a good business move. And since we  are mostly a democracy, at least the government doesn’t own all business,  then it is easy to assume that these places are in business for the single reason of profit, not the greater good of humanity. Perhaps the government should step in and force things, but what part of the capitalist system would that brake? Surely either way there is consequences to consider.
snippet.textOriginal: If capitalism works then a company will pop up that doesn’t do these things and fill a massive need and make lots of money. Or perhaps there really isn’t a massive need for this and all the companies are doing it because most people actually don’t care if they can fix it themselves, and the benefits of allowing that small percentage to do so is not a good business move. And since we  are mostly a democracy, at least the government doesn’t own all business,  then it is easy to assume that these places are in business for the single reason of profit, not the greater good of humanity. snippet.textDisplay: I say write a law that gives right to repair with exceptions.  For industries that are deemed critical to survival of the country (farming and whatever else the lawyers can argue in court), diagnostics must be provided within one hour on site of the malfunction and repairs must be conducted by the manufacturer in a manner that minimally impacts the business that posseses the failed equipment.  If the manufacturer cannot meet this requirement, then the manufacturer must make available to the person in possession of the equipment the means for them to repair the equipment either themselves or through a service of their choosing.
snippet.textOriginal: I say write a law that gives right to repair with exceptions. If the manufacturer cannot meet this requirement, then the manufacturer must make available to the person in possession of the equipment the means for them to repair the equipment either themselves or through a service of their choosing.

snippet.textDisplay: Is there a way to modernize the older equipment, that’s easy to work on, and still runs?

snippet.textDisplay: i've seen old soviet tractors from the 70-80s run until today, they've been in trafic accidents, have been in a lake underwater, have rolled over dozens of times, the engine and other parts have been reasembled by hand for hundreds of times yet it still works, the only electronics there is the starter and the lights

snippet.textDisplay: Unlucky for them they are trying to rip off some of the most skilled and resourceful people on the planet...the farmers🙂. No the new tractors won’t last. The vehicles are designed to be beyond economic repair and maintenance after a fix terms/hours use. The company may even send them self destruct messages, like a large computer manufacturer we know about.

snippet.textDisplay: The car industry has been doing this forever. Farcical "engine malfunction" codes and idiot lights that make people bring their cars to stealerships, specialised bolts and fixtures, specialist software to do a damn brake job. They are forcing people to repair at shops, especially the branded workshop. It's disgusting.
snippet.textOriginal: The car industry has been doing this forever. They are forcing people to repair at shops, especially the branded workshop. It's disgusting.
